questions.text: Pawn ball megakaryocytes are characteristic of: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pawn ball megakaryocytes are a characteristic morphological finding in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). These abnormal megakaryocytes have separated nuclear lobes instead of the normal single multi-lobated nucleus. The presence of these distinctive megakaryocytes is part of the dysmegakaryopoiesis that occurs in MDS, along with other features like ringed sideroblasts and pseudo-Pelger-Huet neutrophils. These morphological abnormalities reflect the underlying maturation defect at the level of myeloid stem cells that characterizes MDS.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura - This is incorrect. In ITP, megakaryocytes are typically normal or increased in number, but they do not show the characteristic pawn ball morphology. ITP is an immune-mediated disorder characterized by antibody destruction of platelets.
  • • Option B. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura
  • • Option C. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura - This is incorrect. TTP is characterized by microthrombi formation due to abnormally large von Willebrand factor multimers. The bone marrow findings in TTP do not typically include pawn ball megakaryocytes.
  • • Option C. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura
  • • Option D. Chloramphenicol toxicity - This is incorrect. Chloramphenicol toxicity can cause bone marrow suppression and aplasia, but it is not specifically associated with pawn ball megakaryocytes. It tends to cause a general hypocellularity rather than dysplastic changes.
  • • Option D. Chloramphenicol toxicity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pawn ball megakaryocytes, with their distinctive separated nuclear lobes, are a characteristic morphological finding in myelodysplastic syndromes and reflect the dysplastic changes in megakaryopoiesis that are a hallmark of this group of disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is diagnostic for mixed connective tissue disease? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mixed connective tissue disease is characterized by high titers of antibodies to U1 ribonucleoprotein (U1-RNP). This antibody is considered diagnostic for the condition, which presents with clinical features that overlap with those of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Patients typically present with synovitis of the fingers, Raynaud phenomenon, myositis, and renal involvement, which usually responds well to corticosteroids, at least in the short term.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Anti-nuclear antibody - While anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are present in mixed connective tissue disease, they are not specific for this condition. ANAs are found in many autoimmune diseases including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and Sjögren syndrome, so their presence alone cannot differentiate mixed connective tissue disease from other connective tissue disorders.
  • • Option A. Anti-nuclear antibody
  • • Option B. SCL-70 antibody - SCL-70 antibody (anti-DNA topoisomerase I) is associated with systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), particularly the diffuse cutaneous form with increased risk of pulmonary fibrosis and peripheral vascular disease. It is not characteristic of mixed connective tissue disease.
  • • Option B. SCL-70 antibody
  • • Option D. Anti-CCP antibody - Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis. They are not typically found in mixed connective tissue disease and are used to differentiate rheumatoid arthritis from other forms of inflammatory arthritis.
  • • Option D. Anti-CCP antibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High titres of antibodies to U1 ribonucleoprotein (U1-RNP) are the serological hallmark and diagnostic marker for mixed connective tissue disease, a condition with overlapping features of several autoimmune disorders including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with a lesion in the right eye and the histopathological image showed Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the likely diagnosis? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Retinoblastoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of a lesion in the eye of a young child, along with the histopathological finding of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (small round blue tumor cells), strongly suggests the diagnosis of retinoblastoma.
  • • Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina that primarily affects young children. It arises from immature retinal cells called retinoblasts. The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes is a characteristic histopathological feature of retinoblastoma. These rosettes are true rosettes, consisting of a ring of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen, resembling the primitive neuroepithelium.
  • • It is important to distinguish Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes from Homer Wright rosettes, which are pseudo-rosettes. Homer Wright rosettes are characterized by tumor cells arranged around a central neuropil (tangled cell processes) and are seen in various tumors of neuroectodermal origin, such as neuroblastoma and medulloblastoma.
  • • While retinoblastoma can show both true rosettes (Flexner-Wintersteiner) and pseudo-rosettes (Homer Wright), the presence of true rosettes is more specific for retinoblastoma in the context of an ocular tumor in a young child.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Ocular melanoma: Ocular melanoma is a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes in the eye. It is more common in adults and does not typically show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology.
  • • Option B. Ocular melanoma:
  • • Option C. Rhabdomyosarcoma: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of skeletal muscle origin. While it can occur in the orbit, it does not show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology.
  • • Option C. Rhabdomyosarcoma:
  • • Option D. Optic nerve glioma: Optic nerve glioma is a benign tumor arising from glial cells of the optic nerve. It is more common in children with neurofibromatosis type 1 but does not typically show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology.
  • • Option D. Optic nerve glioma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (true rosettes) on histopathology of an ocular lesion in a young child is highly suggestive of retinoblastoma. It is important to distinguish these true rosettes from Homer Wright pseudo-rosettes, which can be seen in various other neuroectodermal tumors.

questions.text: The mutations/changes that convert proto-oncogene to oncogene include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Enhancer deletion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transformation of proto-oncogene (i.e., normal cell proliferation gene) to oncogenes (i.e., cancer cell proliferation gene) may occur by three mechanisms:
  • ➤ Point mutations i.e., an alteration of a single base in the DNA chain. Eg:- RAS oncogene carried in many human tumors such as bladder cancer, pancreatic adenocarcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma. Point mutations, deletions, or insertions in the promoter region of a proto-oncogene that led to increased transcription. Chromosomal translocations i.e., transfer of a portion of one chromosome carrying protooncogene to another chromosome and making it independent of growth controls. Eg :- Philadelphia chromosome seen in 95% cases of chronic myelogenous leukemia in which c-ABL protooncogene on chromosome 9 is translocated to chromosome 22. Gene amplification i.e., increasing the number of copies of DNA sequence in protooncogene leading to increased mDNA and thus increased or overexpressed gene product. Eg:- Neuroblastoma having n-MYC HSR region, ERB-B1 in breast and ovarian cancer.
  • ➤ Point mutations i.e., an alteration of a single base in the DNA chain. Eg:- RAS oncogene carried in many human tumors such as bladder cancer, pancreatic adenocarcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma. questions.text: All of the following are side effects of nitrates, EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The adverse effects of nitrates are primarily related to their vasodilatory properties. These include fullness in head, throbbing headache, flushing, weakness, sweating, palpitation, dizziness and fainting. These symptoms occur due to postural hypotension and can be mitigated by lying down. Gastrointestinal disturbances are not characteristic side effects of nitrate therapy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Orthostatic hypotension - Postural (orthostatic) hypotension is a well-documented side effect of nitrates. Standing still and alcohol consumption can accentuate this effect due to enhanced peripheral pooling of blood. Option B. Tachycardia - With large doses of nitrates and significant drops in mean blood pressure, reflex sympathetic stimulation occurs, leading to tachycardia and increased cardiac contractility. This can paradoxically increase cardiac work and potentially precipitate angina. Option D. Tachyphylaxis - Tolerance (tachyphylaxis) to the hemodynamic and anti-ischemic effects of nitrates develops in a dose and duration-dependent manner when they are continuously present in the body. This tolerance wanes rapidly (within hours) when the body is free of the drug.
  • • Option A. Orthostatic hypotension - Postural (orthostatic) hypotension is a well-documented side effect of nitrates. Standing still and alcohol consumption can accentuate this effect due to enhanced peripheral pooling of blood.
  • • Option A. Orthostatic hypotension
  • • Option B. Tachycardia - With large doses of nitrates and significant drops in mean blood pressure, reflex sympathetic stimulation occurs, leading to tachycardia and increased cardiac contractility. This can paradoxically increase cardiac work and potentially precipitate angina.
  • • Option B. Tachycardia -
  • • Option D. Tachyphylaxis - Tolerance (tachyphylaxis) to the hemodynamic and anti-ischemic effects of nitrates develops in a dose and duration-dependent manner when they are continuously present in the body. This tolerance wanes rapidly (within hours) when the body is free of the drug.
  • • Option D. Tachyphylaxis -

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nitrates produce side effects primarily related to vasodilation and can lead to tolerance with continuous use, but gastrointestinal disturbances are not characteristic of this drug class.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl was brought to the OPD with complaint of delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, and secondary sexual development. On examination, there was webbed neck and widely spaced nipples. Which karyotype is associated with the given condition? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 45 XO

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation described in the question is characteristic of Turner syndrome, a genetic disorder caused by complete or partial absence of one X chromosome in females. The key features that suggest Turner syndrome in this patient are:
  • • Delayed puberty and primary amenorrhea: Due to the presence of streak gonads (non-functional ovaries) in Turner syndrome, patients often experience delayed puberty and primary amenorrhea (absence of menstrual periods). Lack of secondary sexual development: The absence of functional ovaries leads to a lack of estrogen production, resulting in poor development of secondary sexual characteristics, such as breast development and pubic hair growth. Webbed neck: A short, wide neck with excess skin folds (webbing) is a common physical feature in Turner syndrome. Widely spaced nipples (shield chest): This is another characteristic physical finding in Turner syndrome, resulting from the altered body proportions.
  • • Delayed puberty and primary amenorrhea: Due to the presence of streak gonads (non-functional ovaries) in Turner syndrome, patients often experience delayed puberty and primary amenorrhea (absence of menstrual periods).
  • • Delayed puberty and primary amenorrhea:
  • • Lack of secondary sexual development: The absence of functional ovaries leads to a lack of estrogen production, resulting in poor development of secondary sexual characteristics, such as breast development and pubic hair growth.
  • • Lack of secondary sexual development:
  • • Webbed neck: A short, wide neck with excess skin folds (webbing) is a common physical feature in Turner syndrome.
  • • Webbed neck:
  • • Widely spaced nipples (shield chest): This is another characteristic physical finding in Turner syndrome, resulting from the altered body proportions.
  • • Widely spaced nipples (shield chest):
  • • The karyotype associated with classic Turner syndrome is 45,X (also written as 45,XO), indicating the presence of only one X chromosome instead of the normal two in females. This monosomy of the X chromosome is responsible for the clinical features observed in Turner syndrome.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 47, XXX (Triple X syndrome): This karyotype is associated with an extra X chromosome in females but does not typically present with the features described in the question.
  • • Option A. 47, XXX (Triple X syndrome):
  • • Option B. 46, XX: This is the normal female karyotype and does not explain the clinical presentation of the patient.
  • • Option B. 46, XX:
  • • Option D. 47, XXY (Klinefelter syndrome): This karyotype is associated with an extra X chromosome in males and presents with different clinical features, such as tall stature, gynecomastia, and hypogonadism.
  • • Option D. 47, XXY (Klinefelter syndrome):
  • • Additional information:
  • • Additional information:
  • • Patients with Turner syndrome are at increased risk of various complications, such as:
  • • Congenital heart defects (e.g., coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve) Metabolic syndrome (obesity, insulin resistance, dyslipidemia) Autoimmune disorders (e.g., Hashimoto's thyroiditis, celiac disease) Osteoporosis due to estrogen deficiency
  • • Congenital heart defects (e.g., coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve)
  • • Metabolic syndrome (obesity, insulin resistance, dyslipidemia)
  • • Autoimmune disorders (e.g., Hashimoto's thyroiditis, celiac disease)
  • • Osteoporosis due to estrogen deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Turner syndrome, characterized by the 45,XO karyotype, should be suspected in a female patient presenting with delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, lack of secondary sexual development, and characteristic physical features such as webbed neck and widely spaced nipples.

questions.text: Which form of heavy chain disease is most commonly associated with systemic lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly? (Twisted PYQ)

It often presents with systemic lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and, in some cases, symptoms of immunodeficiency. Unlike alpha chain disease, which primarily affects the intestinal mucosa, gamma chain disease is more systemic in nature, with lymphoproliferative involvement.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Alpha chain disease is the most prevalent form of heavy chain disease but is primarily associated with gastrointestinal symptoms due to mucosal infiltration in the small intestine, not systemic lymphadenopathy.

  • • Option C: Mu chain disease is exceedingly rare and often presents with features similar to chronic lymphocytic leukemia or lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a history of chronic atrial fibrillation and previous rheumatic fever presents with severe fatigue and palpitations. He dies suddenly, and autopsy findings reveal a mitral valve with a "fish mouth" appearance and superimposed vegetations. What is the most likely cause of death in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)

options.label: A
options.text: Infective endocarditis on a rheumatic valve

options.label: B
options.text: Calcification and fibrosis of Mitral Valve

options.label: D
options.text: Hypertrophy of the left atrial wall

questions.correct_answer: A. Infective endocarditis on a rheumatic valve
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Infective endocarditis on a rheumatic valve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The "fish mouth" or "buttonhole" appearance of the mitral valve is characteristic of chronic rheumatic heart disease, marked by calcification, fibrosis, and commissural fusion. The presence of superimposed vegetations on autopsy indicates infective endocarditis. Rheumatic valves, due to their deformed structure and altered blood flow dynamics, are predisposed to infection, leading to infective endocarditis. This condition is often fatal if left untreated, particularly in patients with underlying cardiac abnormalities.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B : While calcification and fibrosis are the primary changes in rheumatic heart disease, they do not explain the presence of vegetations in this case.
  • • Option B
  • • Option C : Rupture of chordae tendineae is seen in acute mitral regurgitation but is not related to the findings of vegetations and stenosis.
  • • Option C
  • • Option D : Hypertrophy of the left atrial wall occurs as a secondary change due to chronic pressure overload in mitral stenosis but is not the cause of sudden death in this scenario.
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with chronic rheumatic heart disease, deformed valves are at high risk for developing infective endocarditis, particularly in the setting of atrial fibrillation or other contributing factors. Recognizing this complication is critical for timely intervention and management.

questions.text: An adult patient presents with short stature, blue sclerae, multiple fractures with minimal trauma, and hearing loss. This patient is likely to have a defect in which of the following? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Type I Collagen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of short stature, blue sclerae, recurrent fractures, and hearing loss is characteristic of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) , a genetic disorder of connective tissue primarily caused by mutations in genes encoding Type I collagen (e.g., COL1A1 and COL1A2). Type I collagen is a critical structural protein in bones, skin, and other connective tissues. The defect results in brittle bones, increased fracture risk, and the hallmark blue sclera due to the translucency of the sclera allowing visualization of the underlying choroid.
  • • osteogenesis imperfecta (OI)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Fibrillin defects are associated with Marfan syndrome, which presents with tall stature, lens dislocation, and aortic aneurysms, not the features described here.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option C: Elastase abnormalities are linked to alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, causing emphysema and liver disease, not connective tissue fragility or fractures.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Laminin is involved in the structural integrity of tissues but is not related to the findings in osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteogenesis imperfecta is a connective tissue disorder caused by defects in Type I collagen, leading to fragile bones, blue sclerae, and hearing loss. Early recognition is essential for managing fractures and improving the patient’s quality of life.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with chronic fatigue, glossitis, and a tingling sensation in her hands and feet. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytic red blood cells and hypersegmented neutrophils. Endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely to be seen in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)

options.label: B
options.text: Pernicious anemia with Vitamin B12 deficiency

questions.correct_answer: B. Pernicious anemia with Vitamin B12 deficiency
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pernicious anemia with Vitamin B12 deficiency

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The presentation of chronic fatigue, glossitis, and neuropathy (tingling sensations) alongside findings of macrocytosis and hypersegmented neutrophils on a peripheral smear strongly suggests pernicious anemia , a form of Vitamin B12 deficiency . The atrophic gastritis observed on endoscopy supports an autoimmune etiology, where intrinsic factor production is impaired, leading to malabsorption of Vitamin B12. The neurological symptoms, which are unique to Vitamin B12 deficiency, further confirm this diagnosis.
  • • pernicious anemia
  • • Vitamin B12 deficiency
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Folate deficiency also causes macrocytosis and hypersegmented neutrophils but does not typically lead to neurological symptoms or atrophic gastritis.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option C: Iron deficiency anemia results in microcytic, hypochromic anemia and is not associated with macrocytosis or hypersegmented neutrophils.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Sideroblastic anemia causes microcytic anemia and is linked to defective hemoglobin synthesis, not the findings described here.
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pernicious anemia, an autoimmune condition impairing Vitamin B12 absorption, presents with macrocytic anemia, hypersegmented neutrophils, and neurological symptoms. It is associated with atrophic gastritis and requires prompt recognition and treatment to prevent irreversible neurological damage.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with a history of sickle cell anemia undergoes a blood transfusion. During the transfusion, he develops fever, chills, back pain, and dark urine. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (Twisted PYQ)

options.label: A
options.text: Stop the blood transfusion and perform a direct Coombs test

options.label: B
options.text: Continue the blood transfusion and monitor urine output

options.label: D
options.text: Investigate for hemolysis after completing the transfusion

questions.correct_answer: A. Stop the blood transfusion and perform a direct Coombs test
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stop the blood transfusion and perform a direct Coombs test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The presentation of fever, chills, back pain, and dark urine during a blood transfusion is suggestive of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) , often caused by ABO incompatibility or alloantibody-mediated hemolysis. The immediate step is to stop the transfusion to prevent further hemolysis and systemic complications. A direct Coombs test is essential to confirm hemolysis and identify the underlying cause. Other supportive measures, such as maintaining adequate hydration and monitoring renal function, should also be undertaken.
  • • acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR)
  • • stop the transfusion
  • • direct Coombs test
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B: Continuing the blood transfusion is inappropriate as it would exacerbate the hemolytic reaction and lead to further complications.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Administering antipyretics may mask symptoms but does not address the underlying hemolytic process and is unsafe to do without stopping the transfusion.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Investigating for hemolysis is crucial but should be done immediately after stopping the transfusion, not after completing it.
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In suspected acute hemolytic transfusion reactions, characterized by fever, back pain, dark urine, and systemic symptoms, the immediate priority is to stop the transfusion and confirm hemolysis using a direct Coombs test. Prompt intervention is crucial to prevent renal damage and other complications.
